text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review eeprom metahuman this guy is a
Portland music producer from what I
understand this is his debut full-length
LP album right now with with styles of
electronic music like dubstep future
garage footwork glitch hop wonky
electronic music is really at the
forefront of a lot of new and creative
sounds right now and even though EPROM
is not one of the bigger names in
electronic music right now I think he's
digging for new and interesting ideas
with the best of them me his new album
metahuman and this is such a headphone
album not a phrase I use much to
describe albums only when it's necessary
usually I like to listen to stuff on the
hi-fi
on the speakers but not the case with
this thing though this album's tracks do
have a pretty bold and colorful attitude
that you will find with most beat music
producers of the glitch hop variety he
Proms aesthetic is very quiet it's very
subtle it's like a very calming party
happening between your ears and what I
love about this dude is is how he treats
sound on some of these songs he just
shoots for a lot of synthetic textures
on this thing it sounds like he is
treating and manipulating many of these
sounds very very minimally not a lot of
distortion not a ton of reverb he really
likes to maintain that juicy lush very
electronic vibe there sounds on here
that are of an 8-bit quality there are a
lot of rhythm sounds to me that sound
akin to a lot of those snare and kick
hits that you would usually hear coming
out of an 808 but EPROM finds ways to
kind of sequence these sounds really
interestingly the opening tractor's has
these plinking little tap
and clicks that are kind of rolling
they're kind of stuttering they're just
skittering some of them are closed and
very claustrophobic on the ear some of
them are pretty distant in a very
panoramic kind of way it's like a it's
like turning a rain stick over the
introduction on this track is like
gently flicking microscopic water
droplets at my ears then all of a sudden
this bass II beat comes in it's really
spacious there are a few bouncy echoes
here and there maybe like a higher
low-pass filter on something to kind of
give it a low Phi aesthetic and the
groove on the track is is interesting
because it feels so kind of robotic and
sterile usually something that would
turn me off but I feel like it helps the
track in this case because it brings a
really unique flavor to the song this
track really becomes a half human half
robot incarnate there's something very
strange about this track there's
something very serious about it very
Stern about it but you also have to keep
in mind that there are bangers that come
after this track there are bouncier and
just harder hitting songs to a degree
that come after this track this guy is
definitely not making electronic music
to bore you he wants it to sound like a
good time but kind of a quiet good time
like the track prototype and even though
this track does have one of the heavier
beats on the album EPROM is not about
instant gratification the track opens up
with an eerie synth drum with just so
many layers just a casserole of
synthesizer and it's so thick it's so
beautiful then these arpeggiated riffs
kind of come in and then just starts mmm
denne denne denne denne denne denne
denne antennae it's a great groove it's
just a really kind of dark vibe and I
like how he continues to kind of walk
this weird tightrope or just kind of
meet at this strange crossroads where
the track is kind of loud but also very
soft very kind of bare and skeletal the
track can control after that feels even
more skeletal it's like a dancehall
track that would go over well in
purgatory however around the sixth track
for this thing this album kind
of just jumped ship from the weird odd
and somewhat unique world it had been
building with the first portion of this
album EEPROM starts bringing in these
8-bit synthesizers which make things a
little bit brighter and I feel like I
would like the sixth track that this
starts on a bit more if the beat wasn't
so plainly sequenced I get that this guy
wants to bring some musical variety some
stylistic variety to this album but I
don't think every change adds up to a
phenomenal track the track transparency
has some subtle dubstep influences and
the synthesizers and in the vocal
samples but it's not really that
memorable of a moment on the LP for me
neither is the song variations which is
kind of what the title says it is a
variation on a phrase on an idea kind of
bring it through different phases
this parts hitting hard with a beat this
part is the same musical phrase but it
kind of sounds like it's being performed
with the Spanish guitar that track kind
of wears it to welcome for me really
fast and the song right after that love
number is just unashamed Flying Lotus
worship and not even really like the
best Flying Lotus worship I've ever
heard the last portion of the album
starts getting a little bit noisier a
bit glitchy err and I like that this
album starts strong it ends relatively
strong but there is that kind of dry
spot in the middle for me this dude has
some serious chops too the way he puts
tracks together even if at times the
sounds themselves can seem pretty bare
pretty rudimentary and just simple on
the surface he can really create some
unique atmospheres especially on the
first portion of this LP but once he
started to try on other things that's
when this helped he really started to
lose momentum for me but if you're
looking for an electronic music album
that just brings together like I said
very quietly elements of dubstep music
of glitch hop just some weird
instrumentals for you beat heads then
this is definitely something worth
checking out yeah yeah I think beats you
do yes you make beats yeah you make
beats yes sir you make
beats ah then show me those beats re
a decent set forever
